body.name: The Voyage of the Beagle
body.description: The narrative of Charles Darwin's historic journey that ignited the chain of ideas that eventually led to The Origin of Species Charles Darwin was twenty-two years old and embarking on the journey of a lifetime when HMS Beagle left from Devonport on December 27, 1831. His logbook, which has been condensed below, depicts a naturalist patiently noting geology, natural history, people, places, and events. These exceptional papers include information about the Australasian coral reefs, the Gossamer spider of Patagonia, and the Galapagos volcanoes. These revelations sparked the intellectual currents that eventually gave rise to the idea of evolution and the most divisive work of the Victorian era, The Origin of Species. Read more

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2016
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars This edition is complete, not abridged
reviews.reviewText: The reader of this edition, the great David Case, is wonderful. And of course Voyage is a great work, interesting on many levels, a glimpse of insight and genius to come.Some listeners think that a passage regarding the outrage of the ichneumon wasp paralyzing caterpillars and laying her eggs inside them is missing. It is not missing.In Voyage, near the end of Chapter 2, (it is a long passage, 4 or 5 paragraphs), Darwin does discuss this wasp, and her pursuit of a spider (totally creepy), and mentions that the wasp also paralyzes caterpillars and lays her eggs in them. But the connection between the survival strategy of the wasp to benevolent design is not discussed in Voyage in any edition, audio or paper. In Origin, Darwin writes that this phenomenon can't be consistent with benevolent design. Darwin expresses himself most clearly regarding the practices of this wasp and benevolent diety in a letter to Asa Gray written in 1860. The letter is quoted in numerous Wikipedia pieces on Darwin:"I own that I cannot see as plainly as others do, and as I should wish to do, evidence of design and beneficence on all sides of us. There seems to me too much misery in the world. I cannot persuade myself that a beneficent and omnipotent God would have designedly created the Ichneumonidae with the express intention of their feeding within the living bodies of Caterpillars, or that a cat should play with mice."

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2014
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Darwin's Exciting Adventure as a Young Scientist
reviews.reviewText: I was surprised at how easy this is to read! I was particularly interested in Tierra del Fuego and the Falkland Islands, having just returned from a trip to that area. Also, I am reading another book about the area, "The Uttermost Part of the Earth", written by a man born there in the mid 1800s, son of a missionary. It has been interesting, reading teh books together, because both authors share many experiences, but with often differing opinions. Darwin's descriptions of the geography and the wildlife are wonderful. My one complaint (and it's a big one) is that this is supposed to be the "Illustrated Edition" and there is not one illustration in the e-book. Still, I have really enjoyed the book, and encourage others to try it.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2017
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars True life Adventure
reviews.reviewText: This was a fascinating adventure story from way, way back. The fact that he stayed alive through all his travels on sea and land is a story in itself. I found it easier reading than some of his more serious scientific work. I kind of sets the stage for other work of his. It tells you who Darwin was and what motivated his life's work. Well worth the time to read slowly. I liked it a bit at a time.Mel Cearley

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2017
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Amazing, fascinating book.
reviews.reviewText: It was amazing how he made the journey he took so many years ago come so alive for me. His writing was clear and concise. So much about nature was not understood then. It was literally a new world he spent five years visiting, collecting and organizing specimens. His insights into the lives of the people he contacted were fascinating. He spent time with all sorts: settlers, gauchos, missionaries, leaders, sailors, native people, slaves ( horrified by their treatment).

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 18, 2014
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars My 2nd Favorite Darwin Book!
reviews.reviewText: This is my 2nd favorite book by Charles Darwin, because he tells the story of that great circumnavigation that he did as a young man, at a time when most of South America was still wild.What he saw, probably a first-of-a-kind voyage for any human being, made his conclusions, as told in 'Origin..' unavoidable, of course.But I just like to imagine what it was like for a very young man to embark on what was certainly a perilous voyage that would have him traverse Cape Horn multiple times.Truly a remarkable book and highly recommended.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 1.0 out of 5 stars Bad spacing and small letters
reviews.reviewText: Impossible to read, needs a magnifying glass

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 24, 2017
reviews.reviewText: I am puzzled by the fact that it says it's annotated when it is not. It,nevertheless, is a good reading copy.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 30, 2017
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars A Good Read
reviews.reviewText: As a life-long professional wildlife biologist, I found ' The Voyage of the Beagle' to be a fascinating read. Darwin, the quintessential observer & collector of all things natural, writes in an easy-to-read, travelogue style, while at the same time casting a dispassionate eye on the planet's geology, flora & fauna. Also, I especially enjoyed the book because many years ago I acquired a very nice original oil painting of the Beagle plying its way through the Straight of Magellan, a work which has given me much pleasure over the years.

O livro é lindo. Havia recebido um exemplar com rasgos na capa, fiz a devolução e me enviaram outro. Infelizmente ainda veio com alguns rasgos, mas por serem menores, fiquei com ele mesmo assim.Mas o livro é muito bom

reviews.reviewTitle: An unique edition of "The classic" of science travel books
reviews.reviewText: All scientist should have in his/her libary The voyage of the Beagle. This illustred edition of Darwin book is really beautiful. The image set is estonishing and the edition in the complex is unique.
Teeny tiny writing, I'm going to struggle but it does look good and I read a few pages, yeah, happy I bought it.
excellent los dibujos y los mapasideal para regalobastante mas grande de lo que me esperabaoriginal darwin trip

reviews.reviewTitle: but full of beautiful pictures (Hardcover edn
reviews.reviewText: If you've read the "Origin of Species"; but haven't yet read the "Voyage of the Beagle (1845)", then this is certainly a MUST read. It is an abridged version of the 1845 original; but full of beautiful pictures (Hardcover edn.) and notes from Captain Robert FitzRoy from the 2nd voyage of HMS Beagle! Nice way to publish a classic. Kids too will love it. This was the inspirational journey of Charles Darwin (prior to his publication of the Origin of Species)
